snippet: The number of suicides among people 65 and older has nearly quadrupled in recent years, ranking the country’s rate of such deaths among the highest in the developed world.
abstract: Suicides have quadrupled among South Koreans age 65 and older, making country's rate of such deaths among highest in developed world; dramatic rise accompanies decline in  country's Confucian social contract, in which children care for their elderly parents, as economic success has led to change in social fabric.
lead_paragraph: The number of suicides among people 65 and older has nearly quadrupled in recent years, ranking the country’s rate of such deaths among the highest in the developed world.

headline.seo: In Korea, Changes in Society and Family Dynamics Drive Rise in Elderly Suicides
headline.main: As Families Change, Korea’s Elderly Are Turning to Suicide
headline.print_headline:
Adrift as Structure of Family Changes,
More of Korea’s Elderly Turn to Suicide
